review.reviewBody: I like the Halle II pants a lot better than the Halle I pants. The cut of the pockets are more flattering and the fit is better. The material also seems better in the Halle II. I got the slate green color and love it. Though great for hiking, I think they could be nice for most occasions.
review.name: Love these!

review.reviewBody: these pants fit me very nicely.  I wear them on day hikes and I also wear them as casual pants on an active day so very versatile.  easy to wash - I hang dry but not necessary. colors are great - they seem to match all my clothing
review.name: halle II straight pant

review.reviewBody: The Halle Pants were always my GO-TO.  I bought them every time I saw them on-sale anywhere! The material was durable, rugged, and lasted for ages, while still looking crisp and clean.  I bought the current version of these pants and the material has changed.  It is kind of shiny, the cut fits different.  In the same size I normally get, the pants are shorter. The buttons have changed, and the material pills. So the newest Halle Pants that I have, now look like the oldest. Not so happy with these changes.
review.name: They Changed the Product

review.reviewBody: I wear the Halle I to work, but they are always sagging because of the lower cut.  The Halle II are a much higher rise (not crazy high, but higher than the Halle I).  However, I am straight and slender, but carry my weight in the middle.  These dug in just enough to give me a bit of a muffin top.  They MIGHT'VE stretched out a bit and been ok, but I returned them.  The rest of the pant was great though.  I really liked the more normal sized pockets on the Halle II (the pockets on the Halle I are literally uselessly small).  I think these would work great for ladies that have a more normal waist than I do.
review.name: Almost perfect!

review.reviewBody: Exchanged the Halle II Pant for the Halle II Straight pant.  Both are probably great, but the straight pant is the one for me. Thanks Backcountry for the awesome customer service!! True to size or maybe a tad big, for those on the fence.
review.name: Love these!

review.reviewBody: I love the Halle II pants. The size 8 fit wonderfully weight and height. I am 5'11" 135 lbs. with a 30 inch waist. I also love the cinch string on the inside of the pant that helps the waistband better fit the curve of your waist. Very well made!
review.name: Pants that fit great!

review.reviewBody:
I have multiple pairs of the original Halle's that I love, but wanted a little higher waist so I tried the Halle II.  The cut of the Halle II is roomier overall, I had to go down two sizes.  However, fit seems to be dependent on the color.  Slate Green fits perfectly so when I found Sandbar on sale at Backcountry I ordered two pairs.  Unfortunately I need to return them because they are cut about 1/2-1" smaller than the Green.
For reference, I am 5'2", 118 lbs.  I wear 4S in Original Halle and 0S in Halle II.
review.name: Inconsistent Sizing Among Colors

review.reviewBody: These are not the same.  That said, the 28" inseam short on the straight pant and the 30" inseam short on the non-straight version fit the same.  I needed a size smaller than usual.
review.name: Halle II Pant vs Halle II Straight Pant

review.reviewBody: I recently purchased 3 more pairs of these pants in Sandbar, Slate Green and Moonrock to replace a previous generation's fleet of green, dark blue and khaki. These newer pants feel softer, yet seem equally as durable so far. I like the new features like the slot in back pocket for a pen- great for field work. The zipper pulls are easier to grab. The pant leg roll up buttons are only on the outside of the leg, which means there aren't nubbins rubbing against the inside of your knee. My older pairs, going on 5-6 years now, are now strictly outdoor pants for hiking, rock climbing and chopping firewood, as they're still hanging in quite well for the wear they've had. I always air dry these pants, never in the dryer, and that has lengthened their elastic lifespan. These pants are great for work, around town, physical therapy, etc. I lived in Seattle and walked everywhere in the rain and loved how they didn't get sopping wet like other pants, and they dry fairly quickly. They also breathe well during activity in warmer months, climates. They fit well, are flattering and practical for someone with a more muscular and active build like myself- stronger thighs and butt, longer legs. So grateful for being able to feel good wearing a pair of pants made for active, strong women.
review.name: Highly Recommend

review.reviewBody: These are well made, typical of Prana! I can say they fit true to size, but, it's tricky, as I have the 00/short and the length is good, waist too, but they're loose, not tight fitting on me, which is OK, but I wish they were a little more fitted. I still like them a lot, as they do fit.  I like the height of the waist band, not too high or low. Cinch tie on the waist along with the buttons, which is great for slight adjustments.  Overall, these are awesome, I'd get another color if we had 00/short in stock :) !
review.name: Great Material/ Stretch

name: Halle II Pant - Women's

description: Buy the Feedback Sports Sprint Work Stand online or shop all Bike from Backcountry.com.

hasVariant.name: Sprint Work Stand
hasVariant.description: Buy the Feedback Sports Sprint Work Stand online or shop all Bike from Backcountry.com.

review.reviewBody:
10/10. Sturdy, super easy to put away, light, clamp is micro-adjustable. 
Lightweight but very solid design overall. Quick & easy fold-up, to take on road trips.
review.name: Excellent stand for shop or portable

review.reviewBody: The Sprint (and tool shelf) is much better conceived than the "platform" (or Euro-Type) repair stand that I had from Park Tool.  The Feedback Sports stand reflects a great deal of understanding of the intrinsic challenges that such a device requires.  Unlike the one-fits-all fork drop-outs that Park provides, the Sprint comes with a wide range of inserts to accommodate thru-axles (of varying cross sections and length) and varying quick-releases.  The support for the bottom bracket is adjustable back and forth to take into account both center-of-gravity and wheel base, as are the fork dropouts.  These features make balancing a wide spectrum of bikes well-suited to this stand.   As more riders are buying carbon fiber frames, the clamping necessary to support such a bike becomes increasingly problematic:  too little pressure and the bike moves too much;  too much pressure and you're looking at an expensive repair-in the best case.  Silca sells a Hirondelle bar for $185 (https://silca.cc/products/hirobel-clamp) that will keep your top tube safe, but the bar is multi-faceted and held in place only by rubber straps, which permits the bar to twist, and the bike along with it.  The cost of the Hirondelle bar only  will finance more than half the cost of the far more useful Sprint stand.   There is also   an available tool shelf that can be very convenient.
review.name: "Sprint" Platform Repair Stand

review.reviewBody: Pro mechanics use tri mounted stands. The versatility is perfect. From a quick clean to a drivetrain overhaul, this stand is adjustable to accommodate any project or repair. Adust the height and work on your bike at eye level. And spin it around with ease. After the first use, I immediately realized I have been wasting my money on clamp style stands. I use it with both my carbon road and carbon mountain bike. Some complaints are strange. If you find it too difficult to remove the front wheel in order to use the stand then you probably don't need any stand. Over time a serious recreational cyclist (or racer) learns there are a few "must-haves'. And this is one of them.
review.name: What do the pro mechanics use?

name: Sprint Work Stand

review.reviewBody: My old pants were OR and lasted forever so when it was time for new ones it was a no brainer to go with these.  They are incredibly comfortable.  Very soft and very stretchy makes them great pants for any outdoor activity.  The legs zip off easily and the pockets are great.  Can't say much more about them.  Outstanding quality and a great brand who stands behind their products.
review.name: Great pants

review.reviewBody: have had a pair for year, and just ordered another during labor day sale.  They are durable and comfortable.  The Ferrosi fabric provides a good balance of protection and breathability.
review.name: A favorite

review.reviewBody: The Ferrosi Convertible pant is uncomfortable because there is a fat fold of fabric just above the zipper of the zip off lower leg that rubs against your skin just above the knee, both with and without the lower leg attached to the shorts. I own several other brands of convertible hiking pants and none of them have this poor design.
review.name: Ferrosi Convertible Pants Uncomfortable

review.reviewBody: These are wonderfully light, fit and move really well, and overall I think I'd trust these anywhere. Great pants.
review.name: Comfortable and breathable

review.reviewBody: The best thing about these trousers is that one doesn't feel them at all when being physically active. Anoi great thing is that you can only notice that zip near your knee for the first minute or two, and then you completely forget about it.
review.name: Great material!

review.reviewBody: I wore these pants 32 days straight while walking the Camino Frances in Spain. They were terrific. East to hand wash at night yet be dry in the morning. Lightweight for hot Spanish sunshine yet keeping me warm in the morning. Easy to zip off when your exertions make you sweaty. I didn't even bother alternating with the joggers from another brand, which quickly became my pajama bottoms for cold nights.
review.name: Ideal pants for Camino walk

review.reviewBody: These pants are true to fit, super comfortable, and an excellent choice for those days where the cool mornings turn to hot afternoons.
review.name: These pants are so versatile and Comfortable!

review.reviewBody: Great for the dusty weather and windstorms I've experienced out here. Also great flying pants, good amount of stretch and breathability for sitting on a plane for 6 hours.
review.name: Perfect for travel and outdoors

review.reviewBody: These are great pants. The only downside is the poor quality of the convertible zippers, which was a deal breaker for me... However that doesn't affect the quality of the pants, only its versatility. With that said, I would recommend the non convertible version of these pants anyday. And if OR can fix the quality issue of these convertible zippers, then they would have the best all around convertible pants in the game, on top of already having the best hiking pants.
review.name: Great pants!

review.reviewBody: Purchased for a late summer canoe trip where the mornings and evening were cool but the days were warm. Nice and easy to convert back and forth between shorts and pants.
review.name: Comfortable pants

name: Ferrosi Convertible Pant - Men's

description: Buy the Mammut Tour 40L Removable Airbag 3.0 online or shop all Ski from Backcountry.com.

hasVariant.name: Tour 40L Removable Airbag 3.0
hasVariant.description: Buy the Mammut Tour 40L Removable Airbag 3.0 online or shop all Ski from Backcountry.com.

review.reviewBody: Great bag, lots of room to hold all my gear. If you pack smart, most gear is accessible. rapid deployment of avalanche tools. one big pocket makes it harder to manage gear.
review.name: Great for long day and multi day exploring

review.reviewBody: Easy to use, good quality, overall happy with the purchase.

This float pack is roomy, comfortable, and gives me (and my wife, despite my life insurance policy) peace of mind skiing in the backcountry. I can't overstate the improved comfort over my old pack. I'm carrying more weight, this pack being bigger, but it feels like I'm carrying less. 

I've used it for one season now, and am glad to have it. It's 40L, which is big for some tastes, but for me it's the perfect size for your standard gear plus a few backups, be that a second pair of gloves, extra water, or ski crampons. My former pack was 32L, and it was always a tight fit. 

The only light criticisms I have with it is 1) I wish it had come with a helmet net--the one I bought doesn't fit as well as it should. And 2) the pack loses its structural integrity and folds over a little about halfway up when unzipping. It's a small thing, but an improved design or structure might keep this from happening when you're fiddling around in the snow with gloves on. Slight inconvenience. Still love the pack.
review.name: Great Pack, Peace of Mind

review.reviewBody: Was ready to upgrade to a larger touring pack, and after research settled on this bag, and am really happy with the product. The pack is light, the perfect amount of space for bigger days, colder weather, or even light multi-day travels. It can be tough to find packs that carry splitboards well, and this offers multiple carry options that all allow the airbag to deploy. The trigger is easy to pull. My only design feedback is the pocket where the avy gear goes (shovel, probe etc) is so deep that the gear slides to the bottom of it, and would take longer to get to if you had a full pack. I wish there was a way they stayed close to the top. I think this is a common problem with the larger airbag packs in general though.
review.name: The pack I've been waiting for

name: Tour 40L Removable Airbag 3.0
